author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Why Delta Is Leaving Middle Seats Empty During the Pandemic
description: An executive for the airline explains its distancing practices and approach to cleaning at a time when its biggest rivals are selling all the seats they can.
content: The number of people flying today is down about 75 percent from a year ago. And in the fight to attract those few passengers who remain, airlines have promoted their health and safety policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Dinner for One
description: Tri-tip steak, summer squash casserole, some chicken salad with a rotisserie chicken: Eating alone can be full of joys.
content: Good morning. Had a nice visit with a friend the other evening, sitting on a tree stump in his yard after dinner. He‚Äôd made duck legs, he said, rubbed with salt, pepper and a few generous shakes of five-spice powder, cooked them low and slow on his grill, before blasting them at the end to crisp up the skin. I said that sounded delicious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: ‚ÄòThe Moms Are Here‚Äô: ‚ÄòWall of Moms‚Äô Groups Mobilize Nationwide
description: The movement that started with a few dozen moms in Portland now has offshoots in cities across the country.
content: In the flurry of videos and social media posts that have emerged from the protests in Portland, Ore., activist moms are everywhere. They sing lullabies. They link arm‚Äìin‚Äìarm, forming a human barricade between protesters and federal agents. Some wear respirators, gas masks and helmets. Some hand out sunflowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Tweedy
title: Medical Schools Have Historically Been Wrong on Race
description: While the blatant horrors of the past are gone, the ideas that fueled race-based medicine stubbornly linger. We can change.
content: A senior white physician stands by silently as a white patient uses a slur to describe a Black nurse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: For the N.B.A., a Long, Strange Road Trip to the Finals
description: The league has transported 22 of its 30 teams to a complex in Disney World in Florida to play out the season in a worsening pandemic. Can it succeed without the virus piercing the bubble?
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. ‚Äî LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers has likened his new surroundings to a youth basketball tournament for grown men who happen to be some of the most recognizable sports stars on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Miami Marlins Outbreak Postpones 2 Games and Rocks M.L.B.‚Äôs Return
description: Four days after baseball restarted its long-delayed season, a wave of positive coronavirus tests cast the league‚Äôs plans into serious doubt.
content: The return of Major League Baseball took a troubling turn on Monday when a looming threat became reality: an outbreak of positive coronavirus tests within a team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The Doctor Behind the Disputed Covid Data
description: Dr. Sapan Desai, who supplied the data for two prominent and later retracted studies, is said to have a history of cutting corners and misrepresenting information in pursuit of his ambitions.
content: A college degree at 19. A medical school graduate with a Ph.D. at 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: With Eating Disorders, Looks Can Be Deceiving
description: Distorted eating behaviors occur in young people irrespective of their weight, gender, race, ethnicity or sexual orientation.
content: Appearances, as I‚Äôm sure you know, can be deceiving. In one all-too-common example, adolescents and young adults with disordered eating habits or outright eating disorders often go unrecognized by both parents and physicians because their appearance defies common beliefs: they don‚Äôt look like they have an eating problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What‚Äôs on TV Monday: A Penn and Teller Special and ‚ÄòGood Deeds‚Äô
description: The illusionist duo‚Äôs second quarantine event airs on the CW. And a Tyler Perry romantic drama arrives on Netflix and Amazon.
content: TYLER PERRY‚ÄôS GOOD DEEDS (2012) Stream on Hulu and Amazon; rent on iTunes, Vudu and YouTube. Tyler Perry wrote, directed, co-produced and starred in this modern Cinderella story. Perry plays Wesley Deeds, a wealthy businessman who discovers that Lindsay (Thandie Newton), a cleaner at his company, is being threatened with eviction. After Lindsay challenges Wesley‚Äôs ability to understand her predicament, he steps in to help her and her young daughter. The assistance ultimately goes both way. Lindsay encourages Wesley to forge his own path and reconnect with his passions. As David DeWitt wrote in his review for The New York Times, ‚Äúshe saves him right back.‚Äù Eventually a romantic connection forms between them despite Wesley‚Äôs relationship with his fianc√©e, Natalie (Gabrielle Union).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Shelving Units
description: If you‚Äôre overrun with clutter or don‚Äôt have enough closet space, open shelving could be the answer.
content: If your home feels overrun by clutter, but your closets are already stuffed, adding a shelving unit can help get things in order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: National Guard Officer Says Police Used ‚ÄòExcessive‚Äô Force at White House Clash
description: An Army National Guard officer at Lafayette Square plans to tell lawmakers that the Park Police unleashed an ‚Äúunprovoked escalation‚Äù on peaceful protesters last month.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî An Army National Guard officer who was called in to enforce the crackdown on protests in Lafayette Square last month will tell lawmakers that the demonstrators were peaceful and ‚Äúsubjected to an unprovoked escalation and excessive use of force,‚Äù according to written testimony made public on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beppe Severgnini
title: Italy Is Slowly Waking From the Nightmare
description: This is a very strange, subdued summer for a country with an economy that relies heavily on tourism and merrymaking. But E.U. aid is on the way.
content: ROME ‚Äî Streets are quiet, squares are empty, you can hear the gurgling of the city‚Äôs ubiquitous fountains in the daytime. The platoons of Chinese tourists are nowhere to be seen; the American travelers ‚Äî their hats, their sandals, their holiday shorts ‚Äî have disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey A. Rosen
title: The Death Penalty Can Ensure ‚ÄòJustice Is Being Done‚Äô
description: A top Justice Department official says for many Americans the death penalty is a difficult issue on moral, religious and policy grounds. But as a legal issue, it is straightforward.
content: This month, for the first time in 17 years, the United States resumed carrying out death sentences for federal crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: The German economy shows signs of rebounding.
description: Germany is bouncing back quickly from the pandemic, according to a survey of businesses that is a reliable weather vane of the direction of Europe‚Äôs largest economy. But economists cautioned that a return to normal is still a long way off.
content: Germany is bouncing back quickly from the pandemic, according to a survey of businesses that is a reliable weather vane of the direction of Europe‚Äôs largest economy. But economists cautioned that a return to normal is still a long way off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Frozen Vegan Meals From the Chef Matthew Kenney
description: His PlantMade line includes Buffalo cauliflower bites and cacio e pepe ‚Äúmac and cheeze.‚Äù
content: Matthew Kenney, the classically trained chef turned vegan ambassador and restaurateur, has introduced a collection of plant-based frozen dishes. His new PlantMade line includes Buffalo cauliflower bites, cacio e pepe ‚Äúmac and cheeze,‚Äù chickpea curry, jackfruit enchiladas and carnitas, and Korean meatless balls. A sampling of these proved nicely seasoned and satisfying single servings. Mr. Kenney‚Äôs company is collaborating with Golden Platter Foods of Newark, which specializes in frozen chicken nuggets and patties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Of Wine, Hand Sanitizer and Heartbreak
description: Between the coronavirus and the Trump tariffs, the French wine market has collapsed. So winemakers are ‚Äî sadly ‚Äî sending their excess product off to another life as hand sanitizer.
content: HUNAWIHR, France ‚Äî The tanker-truck pulled up and it was time to let it go. The decision to send the wine to the distillery had been made weeks ago. It still hurt. Soon the wine would be sanitizing hand gel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: They Crossed Oceans to Lift Their Families Out of Poverty. Now, They Need Help.
description: As the pandemic destroys paychecks, migrant workers are sending less money home, threatening an increase in poverty from South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa to Eastern Europe and Latin America.
content: LONDON ‚Äî For more than a decade, Flavius Tudor has shared the money he has made in England with his mother in Romania, regularly sending home cash that enabled her to buy medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: Drone Music, Stretched and Sliced
description: David First‚Äôs new album, ‚ÄúThe Consummation of Right and Wrong,‚Äù attempts to reconcile ideas about melody and sustained tones.
content: In late 2017, when David First announced a drone-music performance in Brooklyn, I circled the date on my calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chesa Boudin
title: The Police Answer to Us. What Will We Do About It?
description: Local prosecutors shouldn‚Äôt trust the reports of officers with prior misconduct.
content: The failure of both Congress and state legislatures to respond to the murder of George Floyd with any meaningful action reminds us that our nation‚Äôs attempts at reform can often amount to nothing. We need to look elsewhere for reform ‚Äî to local prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Listening in the Dark to a Cruel Tale of ‚ÄòTrue History‚Äô
description: Shaun Prendergast‚Äôs play, written to be performed in darkness, asks audiences to imagine what the ‚Äúugliest woman in the world‚Äù looks like.
content: Submerged in shadow, we are surrounded by a 19th-century freak show. Ugly phrase, yes, but that‚Äôs what it is ‚Äî a carnival sideshow of human beings whose appearance promises the thrill of shock for paying customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anya Kamenetz
title: I Was a Screen Time Expert. Then the Coronavirus Happened.
description: An author reflects on her pre-pandemic pronouncements about children‚Äôs technology use and offers new advice, like focus on feelings, not screens.
content: Before the pandemic, I was a parenting expert. It was a cushy gig. In 2019, I boarded 34 flights. I checked into nice hotels, put on makeup and fitted jewel-toned dresses, strode onto stages large and dinky, and tried to project authoritative calm. I told worried parents about the nine signs of tech overuse, like ditching sleep for screens. I advised them to write a ‚Äúfamily media contract‚Äù and trust, but verify, their tweens‚Äô doings online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Says It Thwarted a Hezbollah Raid at Lebanon Border
description: The Israeli military says it repelled a raid by Hezbollah in a disputed area along its northern border. Hezbollah denied carrying out an operation. No casualties were reported.
content: JERUSALEM ‚Äî The Israeli military said Monday that it had thwarted a raid by a Hezbollah ‚Äúterrorist squad‚Äù in a disputed area along its northern border with Lebanon, resulting in an exchange of fire that capped days of mounting tension there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Jesse Drucker
title: The race for a coronavirus vaccine is making some corporate insiders very rich.
description: Across the pharmaceutical and medical industries, senior executives and board members are making millions of dollars after announcing positive developments, including support from the government, in their efforts to fight Covid-19.
content: Across the pharmaceutical and medical industries, senior executives and board members are making millions of dollars after announcing positive developments, including support from the government, in their efforts to fight Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Karen Weise
title: Jeff Bezos Cast in a Role He Never Wanted: Amazon‚Äôs D.C. Defender
description: The chief executive, who testifies before Congress for the first time on Wednesday, had taken a hands-off approach with lawmakers in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Last September, Jeff Bezos, Amazon‚Äôs chief executive, rattled off terrifying statistics about the warming planet from the storied National Press Club, two blocks from the White House. Then he said he had something exciting to announce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Darius Settles, Custom Suit-Designer to Ministers, Dies at 30
description: A son and grandson of Pentecostal ministers, he was at the time the youngest person in Nashville to die of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: New Gold Rush Pushes Price to Record Highs
description: Prices are up 27 percent this year, as the Fed‚Äôs policies drive investors to hold more gold.
content: Something shiny and bright is beckoning investors accustomed to the gloomy days of 2020: gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Education Dept.‚Äôs Civil Rights Chief Steps Down Amid Controversy
description: Kenneth L. Marcus was nominated as the head of the Office of Civil Rights in the face of a chorus of opposition. He leaves after a tenure marked by dissension and disputes.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Education Department‚Äôs civil rights chief has for 40 years labored to enforce civil rights protections in the nation‚Äôs schools and universities, but few in the position have attracted as much attention as Kenneth L. Marcus, who will leave the post this week after two years marked by dissension, disputes ‚Äî and significant accomplishments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea Confirms a Defector Swam Back to the North
description: North Korea has accused him of bringing Covid-19 across the border. A South Korean news outlet says the 24-year-old man was wanted for questioning over a rape accusation.
content: SEOUL, South Korea ‚Äî The authorities in South Korea confirmed on Monday that a 24-year-old man who had defected from North Korea in 2017 had secretly returned to the North, crossing one of the world‚Äôs most heavily fortified borders during a pandemic and possibly bringing the coronavirus with him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Women in Publishing, Then and Now
description: A reader praises the ascent of women to management positions but recalls a past when they couldn't advance to editorial jobs. Also: The character of companies.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Cult of Selfishness Is Killing America
description: The right has made irresponsible behavior a key principle.
content: America‚Äôs response to the coronavirus has been a lose-lose proposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Migrants Adrift Off Malta Called for Help. Then They Waited. And Waited.
description: A boat carrying 95 migrants on the Mediterranean floated adrift for more than 30 hours before the Maltese authorities finally brought them to shore under intense pressure.
content: The rubber dinghy packed tight with more that 95 people was bobbing helplessly in the Mediterranean on Sunday when the passengers issued a distress call, but help would not come anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Poland Considers Leaving Treaty on Domestic Violence, Spurring Outcry
description: The European treaty was intended to protect women from abuse, but it has become a target for populist and nationalist leaders who claim it poses a threat to ‚Äútraditional families.‚Äù
content: The Polish government, emboldened by a narrow election victory this month and undeterred by criticism from European Union leaders, is considering withdrawing from a treaty aimed at curbing domestic violence and protecting women‚Äôs rights, with the country‚Äôs minister of justice filing paperwork on Monday to start the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Penn Museum to Relocate Skull Collection of Enslaved People
description: The Philadelphia museum, which reopens on July 28, plans to relocate parts of the collection to storage from a private classroom.
content: A Philadelphia museum of archaeology and anthropology will move part of its collection of about 1,300 skulls, including those of enslaved people, to storage this month after students called for it to give the bones to descendants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: N.H.L. Award Races Bode Well for a Compelling Restart
description: When hockey‚Äôs postseason starts this weekend, finalists for the league‚Äôs top awards ‚Äî like Edmonton‚Äôs Leon Draisaitl ‚Äî will get a long-delayed chance to shine.
content: The N.H.L. announced finalists for its major awards last week, and it was both a reminder of how long ago those performances were and how compelling the postseason tournament will be if players can get back to that level of play quickly. The awards will be based on play before the league was shut down in March because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: A Trumpless Future Is Hard to Get Your Head Around
description: Can Biden ‚Äî and his vice-presidential pick ‚Äî take us there?
content: Gail Collins: Bret, welcome to our new conversing day. Let‚Äôs celebrate by disagreeing. This week Congress is trying to work out a second-stage coronavirus relief program. But the president has been stalling in an attempt to get them to cut payroll taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sake and Beer Among the Bases for These Vinegars
description: American Vinegar Works, in Lowell, Mass., produces small-batch vinegars made from stout and junmai sake.
content: American wines, sakes, and craft beers and ciders are what American Vinegar Works uses to produce its line of small batch vinegars. Rodrigo Vargas, who founded this new company in Lowell, Mass., in the northeast corner of the state, researched 19th-century vinegar  traditions to create his line of eight complex and balanced vinegars. Of particular note are his apple and pear cider hot vinegar with some spice, dark porter beer malt vinegar, ros√© wine vinegar and rice vinegar made from California junmai sake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Hotels Are Promoting the Nostalgia of the Family Road Trip
description: Their campaigns have moved from focusing on cleanliness to appeals to people who want ‚Äúto get out of the house.‚Äù
content: As the United States slowly, haltingly reopens, hotels are trying to persuade Americans to make this the summer of the road trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Moderna and Pfizer Begin Late-Stage Vaccine Trials
description: The studies each aim to enroll 30,000 people and determine whether the vaccines are safe and effective.
content: The first large study of the safety and effectiveness of a coronavirus vaccine in the United States began on Monday morning, according to the National Institutes of Health and the biotech company Moderna, which collaborated to develop the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Lewis‚Äôs Funeral Procession Follows His Footsteps Across Bridge
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 27, 2020.
content: ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt carry on, he got in good trouble for nothing.‚Äù
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Migrant workers are sending less money home.
description: The pandemic has jeopardized a vital artery of global finance: remittances sent home from wealthy countries by migrant workers.
content: The pandemic has jeopardized a vital artery of global finance: remittances sent home from wealthy countries by migrant workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: An Evaporating $600 for Millions of Americans
description: Much of the country loses a lifeline as aid talks crawl forward: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Republicans get ready to unveil their latest stimulus proposal, but Democrats say it might be too little ‚Äî and definitely too late. It‚Äôs Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Kyrgyzstan Rights Activist Azimzhan Askarov Dies at 69
description: The human rights advocate, who was serving a life sentence on charges related to 2010 ethnic violence widely criticized as trumped-up, died in a prison clinic.
content: MOSCOW (AP) ‚Äî Azimzhan Askarov, a human rights advocate in Kyrgyzstan who was serving a life term on charges of involvement in ethnic violence that were widely criticized as trumped-up, has died in a prison clinic. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: A Breakfast Crumble for Early Birds With a Sweet Tooth
description: What started out as French toast, a morning favorite at Yotam Ottolenghi‚Äôs house, evolved into this warm, fruity treat.
content: LONDON ‚Äî Years of close observation have taught me this: People are least adventurous in the morning. Even those who would normally thrust themselves into anything new are likely to stop at breakfast. ‚ÄúOh, that looks great,‚Äù they say, ‚Äúbut not so early in the day.‚Äù It takes quite some time for our taste buds to wake up, it seems.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 27, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 27, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 27, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Urban Explorers Give Modern Ruins a Second Life
description: In photos and videos, researchers and thrill-seekers celebrate the allure of abandoned schools, factories, hotels, movie palaces and other forgotten properties.
content: For Jake Williams, nothing means success like wrack and ruin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Did Hearst‚Äôs Culture Kill Hearst‚Äôs Biggest Magazine Story?
description: The workplace environment at the company‚Äôs magazine division was troubled under Troy Young. And it may not have been good for ambitious investigative journalism, either.
content: One evening in August 2018, Maximillian Potter, then a writer for Esquire magazine, was sitting in a restaurant in California‚Äôs inland empire, trying to persuade a man in his 30s to share his memories of rape and abuse at the hands of powerful men in Hollywood in the late 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: A Possible Weapon Against the Pandemic: Printing Human Tissue
description: Bioprinting could be used for testing potential treatments for Covid-19, cancer and other diseases.
content: This article is part of our continuing Fast Forward series, which examines technological, economic, social and cultural shifts that happen as businesses evolve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: A Small Georgia City Plans to Put Students in Classrooms This Week
description: In-person classes without a mask requirement are scheduled to begin on Friday in Jefferson, worrying some parents, students and teachers as the state confronts the coronavirus.
content: JEFFERSON, Ga. ‚Äî When Jennifer Fogle and her family moved from Indiana to Georgia 13 years ago, they settled in Jefferson, a small, handsome city an hour‚Äôs drive from Atlanta, because they had heard about the excellent schools. And until recently, they had little to complain about. The teachers are passionate and committed, and the facilities rival those found at some private schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Small, Enduring Bloc
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Since taking office, President Trump has lost support among most major demographic groups: women and men, older and younger voters, college graduates and non-graduates. But there are at least two big exceptions: Black and Latino voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Inspector General to Investigate Trump‚Äôs Biggest Climate Rollback
description: The agency‚Äôs watchdog office said Monday it would investigate whether the reversal of Obama-era fuel efficiency standards violated government rules.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Environmental Protection Agency‚Äôs internal watchdog said Monday it had opened an investigation into the agency‚Äôs weakening of Obama-era regulations that would have limited automobile emissions by significantly raising fuel economy standards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brendan Miller and Adam Westbrook
title: ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs Ridiculous.‚Äô How America‚Äôs Coronavirus Response Looks Abroad.
description: From lockdowns to testing, we showed people around the world the facts and figures on how the U.S. has handled the pandemic.
content: The United States leads the world in Covid-19 deaths, nearing 150,000 lost lives. The unemployment figures brought on by the pandemic are mind-boggling. The Trump administration‚Äôs slow and haphazard response has been widely criticized. But what does it look like to young people around the world, whose governments moved quickly and aggressively to contain the coronavirus?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: Here‚Äôs the business news to watch this week.
description: üèõ On Wednesday, the chief executives of four tech giants ‚Äî Alphabet‚Äôs Sundar Pichai, Amazon‚Äôs Jeff Bezos, Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook and Facebook‚Äôs Mark Zuckerberg ‚Äî will testify virtually at a congressional hearing addressing the companies‚Äô market power. The companies have a combined market cap of $4.8 trillion, and the executives themselves are collectively worth $280 billion.
content: üèõ On Wednesday, the chief executives of four tech giants ‚Äî Alphabet‚Äôs Sundar Pichai, Amazon‚Äôs Jeff Bezos, Apple‚Äôs Tim Cook and Facebook‚Äôs Mark Zuckerberg ‚Äî will testify virtually at a congressional hearing addressing the companies‚Äô market power. The companies have a combined market cap of $4.8 trillion, and the executives themselves are collectively worth $280 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: That Almost Apology for the 1980 Olympic Boycott Helps. A Little.
description: In the past 40 years, the would-be Olympians of the summer of 1980 have heard a lot of words, but not a full-throated mea culpa for a boycott that accomplished very little.
content: The athletes who would have represented the United States at the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow are an older crew now, two generations removed from missing what for some was a once-in-a-lifetime chance in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Can Trees Live Forever? New Kindling for an Immortal Debate
description: Some trees can live for thousands of years, but we may not be around long enough to really know whether they can die of old age.
content: Trees do not pay taxes. Some seem to avoid death as well. Many of the world‚Äôs most ancient organisms are trees, including a 3,600-year-old cypress in Chile and a sacred fig in Sri Lanka that was planted in the third century B.C. One bristlecone pine known as Methuselah has been alive for nearly five millenniums, standing in a forest in what is now called California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Why Montana Is a Test Case for Democrats‚Äô Winning the Senate
description: The race between Steve Daines, the Republican incumbent, and Steve Bullock could prove crucial in a year when Democrats need to win in conservative-leaning states where President Trump may still prevail.
content: BOZEMAN, Mont. ‚Äî In the deeply polarized election of 2016, every state that supported President Trump backed Republican senators ‚Äî and each state that Hillary Clinton carried voted for a Democratic Senate candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‚ÄòPerry Mason‚Äô Season 1, Episode 6 Recap: Disorder in the Court
description: Perry learns quickly that a courtroom isn‚Äôt the best place to get on-the-job training, especially with a case like this one.
content: The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak. That‚Äôs the discovery Perry Mason makes in his first moments as a defense attorney, fighting for the life of his wrongfully accused client Emily Dodson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump Again Tries to Block Subpoena for Taxes, Calling It ‚ÄòWildly Overbroad‚Äô
description: The president mounted his most forceful and detailed legal attack yet on the subpoena for his tax returns from the Manhattan district attorney.
content: President Trump on Monday mounted his most forceful and detailed legal attack yet on the subpoena for his tax returns by the Manhattan district attorney, arguing the request was ‚Äúwildly overbroad‚Äù and ‚Äúissued in bad faith,‚Äù a new court filing shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Melania Trump Will Revamp White House Rose Garden
description: The first lady‚Äôs renovation of the garden, a signature showcase of power used by presidents for decades, is taking place as her husband enters a crucial stretch of his re-election effort.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Melania Trump, the first lady, announced on Monday a plan renovate the White House Rose Garden, a signature showcase of power used by presidents for decades, as her husband enters a crucial stretch of his re-election effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: In Granada, Dancing Carefully, Respectfully and With an Audience
description: The Compa√±√≠a Nacional de Danza‚Äôs program looked like business as usual, but it came after months of limited activity and strict measures to rehearse safely.
content: When the Compa√±√≠a Nacional de Danza took the stage at the Festival Internacional de M√∫sica y Danza de Granada in southern Spain on Wednesday, it was in many ways like any other dance performance: A couple performed a touching Bournonville pas de deux; an ensemble of 21 dancers wearing loose, pale gray costumes premiered a new work, set to music by Juan Cris√≥stomo Arriaga, a 19th-century Spanish musical prodigy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: We‚Äôll Be Wearing Masks for a While. Why Not Make Them Nice?
description: Motorized air purifiers and heated sanitizers. Breathable fabrics and chic prints. With face coverings here to stay, consumers are starting to demand more than cheap throwaways.
content: TOKYO ‚Äî Rieko Kawanishi is the first to admit that the pearl-laden mask she designed is not the most effective defense against the coronavirus. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs full of holes,‚Äù she said with a laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: N.Y.C. Seal, With a Native American in Loincloth, Faces Scrutiny
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said it was worth examining if the seal, which dates to 1914, ‚Äúmakes sense for the 21st century.‚Äù
content: It features a Native American in a breechcloth and an early American settler holding a long rope with what appears to be a loop on its end, and for more than a century, it has served as the official seal of New York City ‚Äî but perhaps not for much longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $900,000 Homes in California
description: A 1910 cottage in Pacific Grove, a townhouse in Oceanside and a Craftsman bungalow in Pasadena.
content: Pacific Grove, a city of about 15,000, is on the northern tip of the Monterey Peninsula. Founded in 1875, it is the site of the Point Pinos Lighthouse, which dates to 1855 and is the oldest continuously operating lighthouse on the West Coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Rethinking the pandemic mask, with elegant design or useful technology.
description: As countries around the world tighten rules on mask-wearing, consumers are demanding more from their face coverings. And companies are responding.
content: As countries around the world tighten rules on mask-wearing, consumers are demanding more from their face coverings. And companies are responding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Boris Johnson‚Äôs New Tactic Against the Virus: Urge Britons to Lose Weight
description: The prime minister, who cited his own problems with obesity, said his hospitalization with Covid-19 had prompted his push to tighten regulations on junk food.
content: LONDON ‚Äî Britain will crack down on junk food advertising and introduce calorie counts on menus in an effort to tackle obesity and ease the pressure on the country‚Äôs National Health Service amid the coronavirus pandemic, the government said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Hilary Mantel and Anne Tyler in Running for Booker Prize
description: ‚ÄúThe Mirror and the Light,‚Äù the conclusion to Mantel‚Äôs Thomas Cromwell trilogy, is one of 13 books nominated for this prestigious British literary award.
content: LONDON ‚Äî Hilary Mantel‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Mirror and the Light‚Äù ‚Äî the conclusion to her Thomas Cromwell trilogy ‚Äî was announced here on Tuesday as one of 13 novels competing for this year‚Äôs Booker Prize, the British literary award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adom Getachew
title: Colonialism Made the Modern World. Let‚Äôs Remake It.
description: This is what real ‚Äúdecolonization‚Äù should look like.
content: ‚ÄúDecolonize this place!‚Äù ‚ÄúDecolonize the university!‚Äù ‚ÄúDecolonize the museum!‚Äù
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: The Pandemic‚Äôs Toll on Children With Special Needs and Their Parents
description: Missing social contacts and altered routines, disturbed sleep and eating habits can be particularly intense for the kids with developmental challenges.
content: Franscheska Eliza has a 9-year-old son with autism spectrum disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, anxiety and sensory issues. Before the pandemic, he was in a program in the Bedford, Mass., public schools designed for children with autism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‚ÄòMemorial Drive‚Äô Powerfully Recalls a Southern Childhood and a Mother‚Äôs Murder
description: In her new memoir, the former poet laureate Natasha Trethewey writes about her upbringing and her mother‚Äôs violent death at the hands of an abusive husband.
content: The poet Natasha Trethewey was born in Mississippi and grew up there and in Atlanta. She became accustomed, she writes in her new memoir, ‚ÄúMemorial Drive,‚Äù to the ‚Äúhair rising on the back of my neck when I‚Äôd hear a certain kind of Southern accent, a tensing in my spine when I‚Äôd see the Confederate flag or the gun rack on a truck following us too closely down the road.‚Äù
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Yellowcard Quietly Drops Copyright Suit Against Juice WRLD
description: The emo band had accused the rapper and singer of borrowing from ‚ÄúHolly Wood Died‚Äù for his hit ‚ÄúLucid Dreams.‚Äù
content: Music copyright cases often come down to esoteric points of law and musical analysis, with lawyers and academic experts dissecting melodies for signs of similarity. But in one prominent recent case, the deciding factor may simply have been whether a rock band wanted to pursue a grieving mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: ‚ÄòChallenge Accepted‚Äô: Why Women Are Posting Black-and-White Selfies
description: A campaign that purports to be about ‚Äúwomen supporting women‚Äù is filling people‚Äôs Instagram feeds with striking, if opaque, imagery.
content: Over the past several days, many Instagram feeds have been overrun with black-and-white images of women both famous and not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Vodka for Gin Lovers
description: Amass, distilled in Copenhagen, delivers floral notes for that martini or tonic drink, without gin‚Äôs lash of juniper.
content: If you prefer vodka to gin, with tonic or in a martini, you might consider trying the new Amass Botanic Vodka from Denmark. It heads in the direction of gin, without the aggressive juniper profile. The vodka is distilled from wheat and mixed with marigold, chamomile and lemon, ingredients that have been processed in an aquavit still, for an 80-proof, delicately floral, citric spirit that‚Äôs mellow on the palate. Though the brand is based in Los Angeles, the vodka is distilled in Copenhagen, and has no connection to the highly regarded restaurant of the same name in that city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Salama
title: ‚ÄòNow we feel powerful:‚Äô Au pairs are seeing newfound choice when picking families.
description: When new visa restrictions confirmed that new au pairs preparing to come to the United States wouldn‚Äôt be able to enter the country, the American families expecting them were left scrambling to find replacements.
content: When new visa restrictions confirmed that new au pairs preparing to come to the United States wouldn‚Äôt be able to enter the country, the American families expecting them were left scrambling to find replacements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Coming of Age on Mars
description: In a new book, planetary scientist Sarah Stewart Johnson recalls how the Red Planet drew her to become a scientist.
content: In the winter of 2004, Sarah Stewart Johnson, then a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was on a field trip in the desert east of California‚Äôs Sierra Nevada. While learning to map geological terrains, she fell prey to an adolescent thrill. Boulders were perched on ledges; when nobody was watching, she would strain and push one over the edge just to watch it roll hundreds of feet, crash and break apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Two late-stage vaccine trials could produce results by November.
content: At 6:45 a.m. today, a volunteer in Savannah, Ga., got an injection that kicked off the first large-scale coronavirus vaccine trial in the United States. Results of the trial could be available by November, said Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Stretching May Have Cardiovascular Benefits
description: A 12-week program of leg, ankle and foot stretching led to vascular improvements, even in areas not involved in the exercises.
content: A program of simple stretching exercises may help improve cardiovascular health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Migrant Workers, Hong Kong Wave, TikTok: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here‚Äôs what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here‚Äôs the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: China‚Äôs Claims to the South China Sea Are Unlawful. Now What?
description: Republican and Democratic administrations have failed to thwart aggressive expansion in one of the world‚Äôs busiest sea lanes. The solution isn‚Äôt flashy, but it could work.
content: With China throwing its weight around in the South China Sea, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo rightly declared this month that the country‚Äôs aggressive claims to offshore resources in the area were ‚Äúcompletely unlawful.‚Äù The message aligned the United States with international law in one of the world‚Äôs most critical waterways and showed support for the smaller coastal states threatened by Chinese bullying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: An American Mustache That Irritated South Koreans Is No More
description: Blaming the summer‚Äôs heat, the U.S. ambassador lopped off a bit of facial hair that had reminded some of brutal colonial Japan.
content: The mustache, a thick salt-and-pepper number neatly shaped into a chevron, had survived questions, protests and even Photoshopped ridicule. But it has met its match: the long, sticky days of a Korean pandemic summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Nicholas Fandos
title: Barr Defends Protest Response and Criticizes Russia Inquiry Ahead of Testimony
description: Lawmakers are expected to press the attorney general on the federal response to nationwide demonstrations, his handling of the criminal cases of Trump advisers and other issues.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Attorney General William P. Barr defended the federal response to the protests and unrest around the nation in recent weeks, declaring in comments released late Monday that the rule of law must be upheld as ‚Äúviolent rioters and anarchists have hijacked legitimate protests to wreak senseless havoc and destruction‚Äù in places like Portland, Ore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: The Real Reason Biden Is Ahead of Trump? He‚Äôs a Man
description: It‚Äôs a lot easier to run a cautious, inoffensive campaign when you‚Äôre not up against a culture of misogyny.
content: A narrative has formed around the presidential race: Donald Trump is losing because he‚Äôs botched the current crisis. Americans are desperate for competence and compassion. He‚Äôs offered narcissism and division ‚Äî and he‚Äôs paying the political price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Beckerman and Noor Qasim
title: The Celebrity Bookshelf Detective Is Back
description: We peer over the shoulders of Gwyneth Paltrow, Regina King, Charlamagne tha God, Yo-Yo Ma and others for a glimpse at their reading habits.
content: Zoom happy hours are far less exciting now than they were in March. So is sourdough starter. A lot of the early preoccupations of our lockdown life don‚Äôt quite have the same charm anymore. (Remember the night we all made lasagna together?) But the chance to speculate about the minds and proclivities of the famous by gawking at their bookshelves never gets old. So after a first foray into bookshelf sleuthing, we‚Äôre back for more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chandra Thomas Whitfield
title: Black Yoga Collectives Aim to Make Space for Healing
description: Instructors and students say that diverse communities can benefit from classes focused on people of color.
content: DENVER ‚Äî Beverly Grant spent years juggling many roles before yoga helped her restore her balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: These Businesses Lasted Decades. The Virus Closed Them for Good.
description: The pandemic has wiped out the longstanding anchors of New York neighborhoods.
content: A gun store that opened in 1911. An Irish pub that had drawn crowds since the Reagan administration. A coffee shop that sheltered frightened Brooklyn residents during the 2001 terrorist attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: John Lewis, Lying in State, Is Honored as Part of a ‚ÄòPantheon of Patriots‚Äô
description: A cross-section of influential lawmakers paid respects to the civil rights icon before his body was moved outside so the public could honor him.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî When the honor guard placed Representative John Lewis‚Äôs coffin in the Capitol Rotunda on Monday, the civil rights icon‚Äôs body lay upon the same catafalque that President Abraham Lincoln‚Äôs did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Eddie Shack, Feisty Wing for Powerful Maple Leafs, Dies at 83
description: He helped Toronto win four Stanley Cups in the ‚Äô60s, his pugnacity earning love in Toronto (and, no surprise, hatred in rival Montreal).
content: Eddie Shack, a colorful, pugnacious wing who became a fan favorite at Maple Leaf Gardens playing for Toronto‚Äôs four Stanley Cup championship teams of the 1960s, and who remained in the public eye as a pitchman on Canadian television sporting a cowboy hat and flowing mustache, died on Saturday in Toronto. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Prosecutors Struggle to Resume Guant√°namo Trials
description: The coronavirus pandemic is forcing the military to consider creating a quarantine zone at the court compound to allow proceedings to continue in the case of the alleged 9/11 plotters.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Finding Balance in a Summer Side
description: Crunchy cucumbers meet creamy yogurt in this cold-marinated cucumber salad.
content: The most memorable summer meals don‚Äôt hinge on a single perfect dish. Instead, it is the interplay of multiple plates and platters ‚Äî like a great mezze ‚Äî that transforms them into an occasion. And a well-executed simple side is as critical to the whole menu as anything that may have taken hours to compose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Chocolate in a New York State of Mind
description: The chocolatier MarieBelle New York has a new collection featuring landmarks from the city.
content: Chocolates that pay homage to New York ‚Äî with colorful local images of the Statue of Liberty, the Brooklyn Bridge, Wall Street and so forth on each square ‚Äî are a new addition to the collections made and sold by the chocolatier MarieBelle New York. Fillings vary, but include toffee, pistachio, espresso and passion fruit. Similar but monochromatic images decorate a box of Thank You New York caramels ($42 for 16), whose sale benefits Citymeals on Wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‚ÄòEllen DeGeneres Show‚Äô Workplace to Be Reviewed by WarnerMedia
description: The decision to start an investigation followed the publication of articles that included interviews with employees who complained of discrimination and mistreatment.
content: WarnerMedia has started an investigation into the workplace environment of ‚ÄúThe Ellen DeGeneres Show,‚Äù the syndicated program that has been a staple of daytime television since 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Hoping to Understand the Virus, Everyone Is Parsing a Mountain of Data
description: The coronavirus pandemic has left ordinary people debating case counts, positivity rates and hospitalization numbers in hopes of understanding the virus‚Äôs path.
content: CHICAGO ‚Äî The latest count of new coronavirus cases was jarring: Some 1,500 virus cases were identified three consecutive days last week in Illinois, and fears of a resurgence in the state even led the mayor of Chicago to shut down bars all over town on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Intermittent Fasting May Aid Weight Loss
description: Obese men and women who restricted the times they ate lost weight and had metabolic benefits.
content: Intermittent fasting is an increasingly popular diet technique. Now a randomized controlled trial reports that at least one version of the method ‚Äî time-restricted fasting ‚Äî may have benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Charcoal Grill That Sizzles
description: YAK Grills, a new hibachi, brings diners around the dinner table to cook a meal together.
content: Even with social distancing, four to six guests can sit around a big table with this cunning new grill in the middle and sizzle their own skewered meats, seafood or short ribs. As the company promises, the grill is safe to use on a tabletop, even wood. With the charcoal lit and roaring hot, I could slide my hand in the space underneath the unit, and it felt barely warm. My teak table came through unscathed. The stainless-steel grill, with a cooking surface of 7 by 15 inches, can handle four burgers, a dozen hot dogs, a couple of strip loins or half a chicken. Notches along the sides cradle nine skewers (at least eight-inches long). Igniting the grill calls for a long wand lighter ‚Äî a chimney won‚Äôt fit, though the company plans to introduce one that will. A carrying case is available.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Mistakes New York Made
description: An investigation into hospitals during the peak of the city‚Äôs coronavirus outbreak exposed significant disparities in health care.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Susan Rice Wants to Run for Office. Will Her First Campaign Be for V.P.?
description: The former national security adviser is on the short list to be Joe Biden‚Äôs running mate. She has never been elected to public office, but in 2018 she took a close look at running for the Senate ‚Äî and at her own political strengths and vulnerabilities.
content: On an autumn Friday not long before the 2018 elections, Susan E. Rice was traveling through the Phoenix airport and watching from afar as Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh moved steadily toward confirmation. The convulsive Senate battle had reached a climax, and for Ms. Rice‚Äôs party an unhappy one: Senator Susan Collins, the Maine Republican, had just announced her support for Justice Kavanaugh, effectively sealing his victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Hundreds of Teenagers Were Dropped Off at a Memphis Mini Golf Park. Chaos Ensued.
description: Around 300 to 400 teenagers gathered at the center, mostly outside, in violation of coronavirus restrictions. Employees hid in the basement, a general manager said.
content: Hundreds of teenagers crowded a mini golf center in Memphis this weekend, leaving flower pots smashed, the concession area in shambles and employees wondering how a putt-putt park could devolve into a ruckus involving the police, a stampede and a viral video of the chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Elon Musk courts more controversy.
description: Tesla has been riding high lately, and so has its billionaire chief executive, Elon Musk. But in recent days, notes today‚Äôs DealBook newsletter, Mr. Musk has gotten into a few public scrapes, including briefly with his partner, the musician Grimes.
content: Tesla has been riding high lately, and so has its billionaire chief executive, Elon Musk. But in recent days, notes today‚Äôs DealBook newsletter, Mr. Musk has gotten into a few public scrapes, including briefly with his partner, the musician Grimes.

author: By Tony Cenicola
title: On the Lookout for Moose on Michigan‚Äôs Isle Royale
description: The remote Isle Royale, tucked away in the northern reaches of Lake Superior, is one of America‚Äôs least visited national parks.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series ‚Äî The World Through a Lens ‚Äî in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet‚Äôs most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Tony Cenicola, a New York Times staff photographer, shares a collection of images from a remote island in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Masks May Reduce Viral Dose, Some Experts Say
description: People wearing face coverings will take in fewer coronavirus particles, evidence suggests, making disease less severe.
content: Researchers have long known that masks can prevent people from spreading airway germs to others ‚Äî findings that have driven much of the conversation around these crucial accessories during the coronavirus pandemic.

content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I‚Äôm Lisa Lerer, your host.

title: Cities in Bind as Turmoil Spreads Far Beyond Portland
description: Galvanized in part by the deployment of federal agents in Portland, Ore., protesters have returned to the streets in Oakland, Seattle and elsewhere.
content: SEATTLE ‚Äî A series of strident new protests over police misconduct rattled cities across the country over the weekend, creating a new dilemma for state and local leaders who had succeeded in easing some of the turbulence in their streets until a showdown over the use of federal agents in Oregon stirred fresh outrage.

content: Kathy Mendez did not think twice on Sunday when her teenage son, Kleimer, asked if he could go play basketball near their home in Brooklyn‚Äôs Cypress Hills neighborhood.

title: Research Boosts Evidence of Masks‚Äô Utility, Some Experts Say
description: Masks have long been known to help stop infected people from spreading the virus, but some research now suggests they also protect the uninfected. President Trump shared a video with misinformation about the coronavirus. Republicans are seeking to cut $600 weekly jobless aid to $200.

title: Trump Announced, Then Canceled, a Yankees Pitch. Both Came as a Surprise.
description: The president‚Äôs announcement that he would pitch at Yankee Stadium on Aug. 15 startled the team‚Äôs officials, who had not scheduled such an event.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî An hour before Dr. Anthony S. Fauci threw the first pitch at the season opener between the New York Yankees and the Washington Nationals, President Trump stood on the briefing room stage at the White House and declared that he, too, had been invited to throw out his own opening pitch.

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cookbook Series Honors Long Island‚Äôs Farmers and Produce
description: Loaves & Fishes, a food shop in Sagaponack, N.Y., is publishing small cookbooks focused on farms and their seasonal produce.
content: Loaves & Fishes, a prepared food shop in Sagaponack, N.Y., is publishing a series of monthly cookbooks based on what‚Äôs grown on local farms. The first three, covering June, July and August, have been released. The next set will appear in September. The starting lineup covers the Green Thumb, Foster Farm and Pike Farms. Each book features a brief profile of the farm, stunning color photography and about 20 recipes developed by Loaves & Fishes, not the farmers. Zucchini-chicken burgers, eggplant and basil salad, mixed pepper salad and Thai coconut carrot soup are all lovely summer recipes that I welcome to the repertoire. But these books are for cooks who do not mind recipe oddities, like egg whites measured in ounces not egg number, and require special equipment, like a Pullman loaf pan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Robert O‚ÄôBrien, Trump‚Äôs National Security Adviser, Has the Virus
description: Mr. O‚ÄôBrien is the most senior Trump official to test positive for the coronavirus.
content: President Trump‚Äôs national security adviser, Robert C. O‚ÄôBrien, has tested positive for the coronavirus, the administration said on Monday.

title: Republican Stimulus Package May Come With a Benefit for Big Banks
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee is preparing to relax capital requirements imposed in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

title: As Republicans Embrace Cut in Jobless Aid, Divisions Weaken Their Leverage
description: The proposal comes after Republicans struggled to iron out their policy differences with the administration and each other. Democrats are all but guaranteed to reject the offer.
content: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Senate Republicans and the White House on Monday threw their support behind a substantial cut in jobless aid for tens of millions of Americans laid off amid the pandemic, proposing a weekly reduction of $400 to a benefit that has cushioned the nation‚Äôs economy even as coronavirus cases continue to rise across the country.

content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Remote work could widen disparities in the labor force.
description: As the shift to remote and contract work accelerates, some workers could see an increase in disposable income and flexibility, but others could be pushed into contracting arrangements that lower their wages and make their livelihoods more precarious. Even highly skilled workers may find it harder to band together to improve their pay and working conditions.
content: As the shift to remote and contract work accelerates, some workers could see an increase in disposable income and flexibility, but others could be pushed into contracting arrangements that lower their wages and make their livelihoods more precarious. Even highly skilled workers may find it harder to band together to improve their pay and working conditions.

author: By James Wagner
title: After Marlins‚Äô Outbreak, Yankees Stay Inside and Wait for Phillies
description: The positive coronavirus tests for the Miami Marlins disrupted the first road trip of the season for the Yankees, who were scheduled to play in Philadelphia on Monday night.
content: PHILADELPHIA ‚Äî The news arrived Monday morning via a cellphone application used for internal communication: The game scheduled hours later between the Philadelphia Phillies and the Yankees is off, nobody can go to Citizens Bank Park, and stand by for further updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Elizabeth Paton
title: Kansai Yamamoto, Designer With Ziggy Stardust as a Client, Dies at 76
description: Unapologetically flamboyant, he shaped the look of David Bowie‚Äôs alter ego and also worked with Elton John and Stevie Wonder.
content: Kansai Yamamoto, the unapologetically flamboyant fashion designer whose love of color, unfettered imagination and exploration of genderless dressing caught the eye of David Bowie and helped define the look of his alter ego, Ziggy Stardust, died on July 21 in Japan. He was 76.

title: The Uncertain Future of Midtown
description: Midtown Manhattan faces an economic catastrophe, a cascade of loss upon loss in the city's corporate heart that threatens to alter its identity.¬†

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Twilight of the Liberal Right

content: Anne Applebaum‚Äôs new book, ‚ÄúTwilight of Democracy: The Seductive Lure of Authoritarianism,‚Äù begins cinematically, with a party she threw at a Polish manor house to mark the dawn of the new millennium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Executes Female Prison Guard, and U.N. Raises Concern Over Afghan Violence
description: The guard was abducted while traveling to her home village and later killed. The United Nations says civilians continue to bear the brunt of the Afghan conflict.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan ‚Äî The Taliban abducted and executed a female prison guard in the eastern Afghan province of Ghazni, officials and relatives said Monday, as the United Nations expressed concern over the war‚Äôs unending toll on civilians.

author: By Jonah Markowitz and Christina Goldbaum
title: Transit Workers Were N.Y.C.‚Äôs Pandemic Lifeline. These 3 Paid a Price.

author: By Quoctrung Bui, Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: How to Test More People for Coronavirus Without Actually Needing More Tests
description: Pooled testing, which can make one coronavirus test as powerful as five, is particularly useful when the infection rate is low. Its use could free up more tests for places where the virus is more widespread.
